You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 280, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 860, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 220, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 728, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 527, 89]]<|/det|>
Find the general solution of the differential equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 94, 593, 125]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}x}{\mathrm{d}t^{2}} -8\frac{\mathrm{d}x}{\mathrm{d}t} -9x = 9\mathrm{e}^{8t}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 537, 92]]<|/det|>
Use the characteristic equation of \(\mathbf{A}\) to find \(\mathbf{A}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 75, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 98, 910, 294]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 330, 920, 367]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve with equation \(y = \ln x\) for \(x \geqslant 1\), together with a set of \((N - 1)\) rectangles of unit width.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 378, 144, 397]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 378, 672, 397]]<|/det|>
By considering the sum of the areas of these rectangles, show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 408, 593, 428]]<|/det|>
\[\ln N! > N\ln N - N + 1.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 409, 920, 428]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 698, 91]]<|/det|>
Use a similar method to find, in terms of \(N\), an upper bound for \(\ln N!\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 416, 89]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has parametric equations

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[319, 100, 680, 122]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{1}{2} t^{2} - \ln t,\qquad y = 2t + 1,\qquad \mathrm{for} \frac{1}{2}\leqslant t\leqslant 2.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 368, 152]]<|/det|>
Find the exact length of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 81, 148, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 75, 536, 109]]<|/det|>
Find \(\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}y}{\mathrm{d}x^{2}}\) in terms of \(t\), simplifying your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 82, 920, 101]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 792, 91]]<|/det|>
Starting from the definitions of \(\tanh\) and \(\operatorname {sech}\) in terms of exponentials, prove that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 100, 584, 120]]<|/det|>
\[1 - \tanh^{2}\theta = \operatorname {sech}^{2}\theta .\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 101, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 380, 724, 401]]<|/det|>
The variables \(x\) and \(y\) are such that \(\tanh y = \cos \bigl (x + \frac{1}{4}\pi \bigr)\), for \(-\frac{1}{4}\pi < x < \frac{3}{4}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 426, 146, 445]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 425, 784, 448]]<|/det|>
By differentiating the equation \(\tanh y = \cos \left(x + \frac{1}{4}\pi\right)\) with respect to \(x\), show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[410, 465, 591, 495]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} = -\mathrm{cos}\mathrm{e}\mathrm{c}\big(x + \frac{1}{4}\pi \big).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 472, 920, 491]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 78, 144, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
Hence find the first three terms in the Maclaurin's series for \(\tanh^{-1}\bigl (\cos (x + \frac{1}{4}\pi)\bigr)\) in the form \(\frac{1}{2}\ln a + bx + cx^2\), giving the exact values of the constants \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 102, 917, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 520, 89]]<|/det|>
Show that an appropriate integrating factor for

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[341, 109, 655, 139]]<|/det|>
\[(x^{2} + 1)\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} +y\sqrt{x^{2} + 1} = x^{2} - x\sqrt{x^{2} + 1}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 145, 276, 165]]<|/det|>
is \(x + \sqrt{x^2 + 1}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 148, 920, 166]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 554, 89]]<|/det|>
Hence find the solution of the differential equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[344, 95, 653, 123]]<|/det|>
\[(x^{2} + 1)\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} +y\sqrt{x^{2} + 1} = x^{2} - x\sqrt{x^{2} + 1}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 131, 715, 152]]<|/det|>
for which \(y = \ln 2\) when \(x = 0\). Give your answer in the form \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 96, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 144, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 828, 96]]<|/det|>
Use de Moivre's theorem to show that \(\sin^{6}\theta = -\frac{1}{32} (\cos 6\theta - 6\cos 4\theta + 15\cos 2\theta - 10).\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 75, 920, 94]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 603, 598, 625]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\cos^6 \theta = \frac{1}{32} (\cos 6\theta + 6\cos 4\theta + 15\cos 2\theta + 10).\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 648, 146, 667]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 640, 920, 673]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of \(\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{3}\pi} (\cos^{6}(\frac{1}{4}x) + \sin^{6}(\frac{1}{4}x))\mathrm{d}x.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 648, 920, 667]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 682, 917, 700]]<|/det|>
